answers.answer: Your concern about your husband is warranted.  He is on good medicine for his lung condition.  Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a slowly progressive chronic disease, more rapidly progressive in those who continue to smoke but never to the degree you describe with a fall in FEV1 from 53% predicted to 23% predicted in less than a year, assuming each of these breathing tests were done with his COPD in a stable state; that is he was not having a flare-up, also known as an acute exacerbation, when the 23% value was obtained.  If that is true, one of these values is not valid.  The 54% FEV1 is consistent with the criterion for moderate COPD, not severe COPD.  If his predicted FEV1 truly is greater than 50% of predicted, it would be unusual for him to, as you indicate, “need to be made comfortable, (with) no energy, very fatigued, with a poor appetite”, on the basis of COPD.  COPD is often associated with depression and, at least some of his symptoms could be due to that.The more likely scenario, given fatigue, no energy and constant thirst is that his diabetes is out of control.  And, if he is on the highest dose of Advair® HFA (fluticasone propionate and salmeterol) Inhalation Aerosol, that could be contributing to poor control.You should have his blood sugar checked, perhaps by you at home, immediately and arrange for him to be seen by his doctor without delay to:  1) assess the state of diabetic control; and 2) repeat the pulmonary function tests (PFTs) and a chest x-ray; and/or 3) request that his doctor arrange for consultation with a lung specialist, also known as a pulmonologist.  Do not delay.

question: My husband is suffering from COPD. In July 2008 he was diagnoss with COPD. His FEV1 PDP% was at 54. He went to the doctor's yesterday. His FEV! PDP% is now at 23. The COPD is progressing rapidly from his doctor's stand point. He is on Advair, Spriva, and Pro-air. This is the only medications he can take because is also a diabetic. What can I do to make him comfortable. Is it normal for him to have no enegry, very fatigue. His appetite is not a well. He is constantly thirsty. This is very hard for us. He is only 39 years old. Could you please tell me what to espect during this final stage. Meaning the complications, hospital visits, etc.. I can not find any information on the internet.Thank you very much for your time.Sincerly,Very concerned wife..
title: Very Severe Stage
